Implementation approach: We will utilize the Flask web framework to create a robust and scalable ticket management system. The system will be designed with a modular architecture, allowing for easy maintenance and extension. We will also leverage the SQLAlchemy library for database operations and the Jinja2 templating engine for rendering dynamic templates.
Data structures and interfaces:
classDiagram
    class User {
        -id: int
        -username: str
        -email: str
        +__init__(username: str, email: str)
        +get_tickets() list
    }
    class Ticket {
        -id: int
        -title: str
        -description: str
        -status: str
        -user_id: int
        +__init__(title: str, description: str, user_id: int)
        +update_status(status: str)
        +get_messages() list
    }
    class Message {
        -id: int
        -content: str
        -ticket_id: int
        -user_id: int
        +__init__(content: str, ticket_id: int, user_id: int)
    }
    class HelpdeskStaff {
        -id: int
        -username: str
        -email: str
        +__init__(username: str, email: str)
        +get_tickets() list
        +assign_ticket(ticket_id: int, staff_id: int)
    }
    class Database {
        +create_table(table_name: str)
        +insert_data(table_name: str, data: dict)
        +query_data(table_name: str, query: str) list
    }
    User --> Ticket
    Ticket --> Message
    HelpdeskStaff --> Ticket
    Database --> User
    Database --> Ticket
    Database --> Message
Program call flow:
sequenceDiagram
    participant M as main.py
    participant U as User
    participant T as Ticket
    participant MS as Message
    participant HS as HelpdeskStaff
    participant DB as Database
    M->>U: create_user(username, email)
    U->>DB: insert_data('users', {username, email})
    DB-->>U: return user_id
    M->>T: create_ticket(title, description, user_id)
    T->>DB: insert_data('tickets', {title, description, user_id})
    DB-->>T: return ticket_id
    M->>MS: create_message(content, ticket_id, user_id)
    MS->>DB: insert_data('messages', {content, ticket_id, user_id})
    DB-->>MS: return message_id
    HS->>T: assign_ticket(ticket_id, staff_id)
    T->>DB: update_data('tickets', {status}, ticket_id)
    DB-->>T: return updated_ticket
    M->>U: get_tickets(user_id)
    U->>DB: query_data('tickets', 'user_id = {}'.format(user_id))
    DB-->>U: return tickets
Anything UNCLEAR: Clarification needed on the specific database management system to be used, as well as the authentication and authorization mechanisms for users and helpdesk staff.
